title: How can happiness be quantified or measured? - Quora

response.answer_text: Human beings are continuously striving to achieve an instinctive concept known as ‘happiness’ yet most have no concrete idea on how to go about achieving it. Most people just settle with ‘an idea’ and believe assumptions of what would make a person happy, but happiness is not necessarily guaranteed. A mass adoption of the concept of happiness is that when everything in life falls into place and we finally have everything one would like to own, we will be happy. “Happiness, as defined by psychologists, is a state of mind and a feeling of wellbeing where a person experiences positive emotions like feeling a pleasant state, being content with one’s life and feeling joyful” Vivienne Lewis (University of Canberra: Professor of Psychology) However, people do not realize that an individual’s perception of wellbeing is highly specialized and personalized, hence what makes one individual happy may not be as effective as ensuring happiness for another individual. There are two main ‘types’ of happiness and humans are rarely in a permanent state of happiness, happiness at times is fleeting, for one moment it’s there, and in a few hours it dissipates, however there are things that can be done to optimize our sense of wellbeing. Happiness is a state of emotional, mental and spiritual wellbeing and results in the release of the neurotransmitter dopamine in your brain. Happiness can be found in two forms: hedonic and eudaimonic. A hedonic state of happiness is when you are experiencing a transitory state of pleasure, consuming a exceptional meal, enjoying a glass of wine, getting a relaxing massage. Eudaimonic state of happiness is related to an individuals’ state of self-realization, discovery, wellbeing, fulfillment and engagement with the environment or society. In both situations, one does not need to be wealthy to experience both states of happiness. How can one seek happiness? Happiness can be experienced by practicing gratitude daily, being mindful of others and investing in personal relationships. Happiness can be harvested by investing time in building your craft or speciality and dividing your time in a balanced manner to distribute a reasonable amount in scholarship, with relationships, and experiences that bring you joy and most importantly by being honest with yourself. If you’ve come this far, thank you for reading and I hope my post was a good experience for you! I wish you the best in your pursuit of happiness! Always know that the power lies within you! If you enjoy my writing, I just published my poetry book on Amazon! Bhavleen Smoot

It is important to consider basic definitions of words which we tend to take for granted in order to understand what they really mean. Happiness is one of those words which has lost its original meaning, and is often confused with pleasure. Happiness is unconditional. The difference between pleasure and happiness is that to be happy does not require certain conditions to be present. Happiness is when you are filled with joy for no apparent reason, when you can just feel full of yourself, of life, without being able to point at a particular event. Pleasure, on the other hand, is when you are happy because of something else. Someone tells you that you are beautiful or handsome, or you are good at something or you win something, and that makes you happy. That happiness is fleeting, momentary and disappears before you know it. It is not true happiness but pleasure. If you are happy because of something else you will soon be unhappy again because the thing that made you happy can be taken away or may disappear of its own accord. You are famous one day, and ignored the next; happy one day and unhappy the next. If your happiness is dependent on outside events then you do not know happiness. We have all fleetingly felt real happiness; when you see a beautiful sunset and something inside wells up, or a new day fills you with wonder. The sunset cannot be bought, it is not exclusively yours, it is not doing anything for you, but it fills you with joy. This is not because of the sunset as much as it is about you being lost in yourself. For a brief moment you are lost to the outside world and its problems, you are oblivious of everything. Everyone has momentary glimpses of real happiness, but it is always very short because you are drawn back into the 'real' world and the problems and stresses and anxieties of the everyday. We start with the wrong position when we call this life of problems and stress the 'real' world. When people are artistic, poetic, creative, we say to them; "get real!" But let us turn the discussion on its head. It is not real to race around from dawn to dusk and beyond, it is not real to eat junk food, it is not real to be anxious and stressed for long periods of time, it is not real to be stretched all the time in both body and mind. The real world is one where we can be ourselves.

It can be, but primarily through subjective means. I suppose you could measure the levels of different chemicals in the brain, but a less invasive and more common method is asking questions. For example, if I asked a random sample of 1000 people in 2 countries to rate their happiness on a scale of 1 to 10 I would get data I could use to measure individuals perception of happiness. I could then compare them to rate the countries on perceived happiness. (2 people could be equally happy, but one had a great life and so feels less happy, and scores it lower, then the one who had a terrible life) However, if I followed a group of 1000 people and questioned them periodically, I could measure rather accurately how different types of events affects happiness. If the group averaged scoring 4 when they were in high school but 6 when in college, 3 when in the hospital, 8 when getting married, etc. even though some would rate high school higher than college, we could accurately say people tend to be happier in college than high school, weddings than hospital stays. If you score your apparent happiness for that day in a journal, you very likely would see trends between events and outcomes. For example, maybe you discover that taking that vacation (average 6 because travel, tired, lost luggage, no rental car, miss your pet gold fish)for a week really did not make you happier than the time you took a ‘staycation.’ (average 8 because slept in those extra travel days, dropped off laundry because saving money on no trip, turned off phone, love that little fish.) We don’t always realize what is making us happy or unhappy. (All data is obviously made up out of thin air for example purposes, of course.)

I have a thinking tool to measure happiness that I call “the empty room paradox.” This is personal. Many people may not agree, but I find it very powerful. Why is that a paradox? Let’s play this thought experiment for few seconds. Imagine you are closed in a tiny room. There is only a bed and a desk. No computer, smartphone, cigarettes, alcohol, books and so on. Nothing at all! Of course you are fed once a day. And you also have a small window from where the sunlight comes in. My guess is that none would ever want to be in such condition. Right? That is where the paradox kicks in. The empty room paradox states that the longer you are able to live in that circumstances, without freaking out, the happier you are destined to be. Why? If you pass the empty room paradox it means that your happiness in not dependent upon external devices (cigarettes, smartphones, computers, and so on). Also, it implies that you have a creative mind, and know how to use it imaginatively. For instance, nowadays we often tend to emphasize virtual reality and how that will be the future for our species. Yet we also forget that virtual reality is and will be always filtered out and perceived through and within our brain. In other words, our brain itself is a virtual device tool that can be used to generate any kind of virtual reality you want. It is only up to your imagination and creativity. In short, the “empty room paradox” is a thinking tool that can be used to measure the level of mental health and future happiness.

It is possible to be happy on a sliding scale. You can measure how happy you are qualitatively… by comparison with other things that make you happy. So you can tell if you are more or less happy than you were yesterday, for example. Most people find that, with some practice, they can have a reliable, though subjective, 1–10 scale, and plot out how happy they are on that scale, using a calendar. Most adults have experienced varying happiness in their life to date. You can make a scale of 0–10 (to start with) where 0 is a neutral feeling of neither happy not unhappy and 10 is the happiest you have ever felt in your life so far. You could use negative numbers to indicate unhappiness. You can use this sort of scale to plot your daily happiness… if you have never done this, the exercise can be revealing. Objective happiness scales are trickier … and would need a medical definition of “happy” related to, say, bloodwork. The trouble is that the word “happy” is not precisely enough defined.

This is a very difficult question to answer. As a construct, happiness is made up of many other sub-constructs. For example, happiness can be made up of a number of sub-constructs depending on the definition one is working with - some of these may be: self-efficacy, embeddedness in a community, optimism, a feeling of being appreciated, and many more. The key to measurement is to use psychological/social scales to measure the sub-constructs, and the findings would then give the researcher an overall view of the construct of happiness. For further information, the following article may prove to be informative: Measuring Wellbeing and Happiness

When reading the How of Happiness I was first introduced to The Oxford Happiness Questionnaire. It tries to answer this question in a standardised and scientific way – so that we can compare our own results over time and see if we get happier or not, and also to compare our score with that of other people. The Guardian has created an interactive version of the questionnaire which you can take here. It consists of 29 simple questions and shouldn't take more than a few minutes to complete.  The lowest possible score you can get is 1, and the highest possible score is 6. The average is around 4.30. If you take the questionnaire now, it will be helpful to note down your score and today's date somewhere. Then you can compare against that at a later point, to see whether you've made any progress in becoming a happier person. There are of course a myriad of other happiness questionnaires, but I found this one helpful. There is also a lot of work when it comes to measuring happiness across a whole population, like in a country. I wrote a blog post about that recently, in case you are interested in what countries have the happiest people[1] and how it is measured. Footnotes[1] The Happiest Countries of the World 2017

That is simple. It can't. Happiness has a different definition for each individual. True happiness (not lust, quick satisfaction, material things) is not measurable. Happiness can be a state of mind, an emotion, a habit, a feeling, and many more things. You could throw out the “on a scale of 1 to 10” and ask someone to rate their happiness at a particular moment but that would be completely relative to their overall happiness and their definition of happiness. People also experience it differently. Some people ars calm, some people are energetic. Some smile or laugh, and some just look at peace, etc etc. I could go on but the jist of the answer is there: you can’t measure happiness.

Happiness is a subjective term and is never constant. Even if means are found to measure a person's happiness, it is not the same the very next second. It varies from person to person. It is a moment to be treasured rather than being measured.

Happiness is generally deemed to be a construct in positive psychology, and so not easily measured directly. It can be measured through a proxy of self-reports (which are highly prone to cultural biases) such as the Satisfaction With Life survey or a ladder from 1-10 asking "how happy are you" with 10 being the highest rung. This ladder method has, I believe, been used across cultures (c.f. Ed Diener) with some consistency and cross-cultural comparability. Several other measures exist that get at some aspects of happiness, but there is no one easy way to objectively measure happiness at this time.

If you’re looking for a philosophical answer, I’m a fan of John Stuart Mill and the utilitarians. Ooh, what a hilarious name for a band that would be! But I digress. Greatest good for the greatest number, look it up! Law students and lawyers frequently try to assess monetary value for pain and suffering. Insurance companies make those kinds of judgments too. If you have access to WestLaw or Lexis, you can look up what the going rate is for losing a leg in a car accident. There will be a medical damages number, and that’s for the medical bills (ER, doctor, surgeon, radiology, etc.). But there will also be a pain and suffering number, and that’s a function of how much “happiness” we feel you lost by losing your leg in that car accident. Fascinating stuff.
